timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure if we should pull this exception down to the storage level.  If we do pull this down, it feels like we should be throwing this exception from the various methods that try to access the store or the chainHead.  But that seems like a mess.  Probably simpler to just return an SafeFuture<Optional<BeaconBlock>> for now?  Or create a custom exception in the validator package?
timeline.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: Going back to returning optional as discussed.
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.bodyText: This change is because the StateTransitionException would be wrapped in a CompletionException?
timeline.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: Yes.  It's not pretty but this code shouldn't be in the beacon chain client at all so I'm not going to try and make it use futures properly here. That will come when it gets rebuilt in the validator client.
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.bodyText: May be worth adding a test to check the behavior when storage isn't initialized.
timeline.author: mbaxter

replies.bodyText: BlockFactory never actually uses the chain storage - it's passed the parent block and state as arguments.  The test just needs to init storage here to generate a block and state that match up correctly - generating them randomly leads to the roots not matching up properly.
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.bodyText: Another option would be to not handle this here, and let the global error handler manage this.  In which case, you'd need to test this with an integration test.
timeline.author: mbaxter

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:PegaSysEng/teku into create-block-api
